A:  You can use the following regex: ^(?!(French:|English:)).*$  This will match any line that does not start with either French or English: >>> import re >>> s = """French:  = English:  French: SURPRIIIIIIISE!!!!!!!!! = English: SURPRIIIIIIISE!!!!!!!!!""" >>> re.findall(r'^(?!(French:|English:)).*$', s) ['French:  = English: ', 'French: SURPRIIIIIIISE!!!!!!!!! = English: SURPRIIIIIIISE!!!!!!!!!']  The ^(?!(French:|English:)).*$ regex matches any line that does not start with either French or English:  ^ - asserts the start of the line (?!(French:|English:)) - a negative lookahead that fails the match if the following is found:  French: - a literal string English: - a literal string .* - matches any 0+ chars other than line break chars, as many as possible $ - asserts the end of the line.

A:  I think the difference is that in English, the word "just" is used to emphasize the fact that the speaker is not interested in the question, but in French, the word "just" is used to emphasize the fact that the speaker is interested in the question, but is not sure of the answer.
